article.headline: Colorado 79, UMKC 68
article.story: BOULDER, Colo. (AP) -- Colorado has no trouble letting freshman Richard Roby and Marcus King-Stockton handle the scoring load. It's a good thing. Both came up big for the Buffaloes Tuesday night. Roby hit five 3-pointers and scored 17 of his 23 points in the second half, and King-Stockton had 11 points and eight rebounds to help Colorado rally from a lackluster first half and beat Missouri-Kansas City 79-68. "We don't view Richard as a freshman or Marcus King-Stockton," said Colorado's Jason Obazuaye, who had 16 points. "They've come in here with the mind-set that they just want to help the team. (They) didn't come in with the mindset that they're all-world, so that gives us confidence to get them the ball." They responded. King-Stockton did most of his damage after Julius Ashby sprained his foot in the first half, hitting all four of his shots and finishing with as many points and four more rebounds than he had his first five games. Roby found his stroke after going 2-of-5 in the first half, hitting a pair of 3-pointers during Colorado's big run and two more on consecutive possessions that put the Buffaloes up 67-57. He finished 8-for-15, hitting 5-of-9 from long range, and had six rebounds. "I got in a little groove," Roby said. "I came out a lot in the first half and the second half I got more minutes and got a chance to get a feel for the game." Quinton Day and Mike English had 17 points each for UMKC (0-6), which looked ragged in the second half after a steady first. The Kangaroos had some success kicking the ball out of the post for open shots in the first half, but Colorado closed down the passing lanes and was better at rotating out to their shooters in the second. Not surprisingly, UMKC spent much of its time forcing shots and didn't make many, ending the half 10-for-30. "I'll tell you what they did, is they turned up the pressure in the second half and we didn't do a good job," UMKC coach Rich Zvosec said. "We lost focus and we got into their type of game, which is up and down the floor." Colorado (5-2) played it the opposite -- the Buffaloes struggled in the first half and started find a rhythm in the second. Pressuring the Kangaroos into mistakes and using crisp passes to get open looks, the Buffaloes went on a 21-6 run, capped by Obazuaye's three-point play that put Colorado up 59-50 with 7½ minutes left. The Buffaloes also did a good job of hitting the glass, grabbing 10 of their 15 offensive rebounds in the second half, which contributed to their 18-of-31 shooting. "We were getting good shots in the first half, they just weren't falling," Colorado coach Ricardo Patton said. "In the second half, we started to attack the zone and drive and penetrate and pitch and get some baskets in the paint, and that opened it up for our outside shooters." Both teams were aggressive defensively in the early going, making it difficult for either one to get into much of a flow. Colorado was sloppy at times, throwing two balls into the backcourt and another into the stands for turnovers in the first 10 minutes. The Buffaloes were able to work the ball around the perimeter for some open shots and took a few bad ones, with few going in. Colorado shot 8-for-25 and was just 2-for-9 on 3-pointers. UMKC had a little more success by working the ball through the post. The Kangaroos did a good job of getting the ball deep even though center Carlton Aaron played just four minutes because of foul trouble, and were even better at kicking out to the perimeter, where they hit 6-of-15 to take a 34-39 lead. Too bad it didn't last. "We ran out of gas," Zvosec said. "We went to the bench and we didn't get any production. We had some guys who had to play minutes that they just weren't prepared to play."
